DOC.HEAD: Canal Opens Under Limited Hours
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Panama Canal reopened Thursday after a one-day closing caused by the U.S. invasion, the only time anything other than natural disaster has halted operation of the 75-year-old waterway. The Panama Canal Commission said the canal will operate only during the daytime until at least this weekend. Commission spokesman Franklin Castrellon said only an average of 12 ships daily will travel the waterway, compared with a normal average of about 33 a day when the canal operates its regular round-the-clock schedule. The 43-mile canal had been closed since 1 a.m. Wednesday ``due to the concern for the safety of vessels and of canal employees during U.S. military activities in the area,'' the commission said in a statement from the Washington office of the canal secretary, Michael Rhode Jr. The commission said there has been no damage to canal facilities.
